item.title: [JRUBY-6847] Add symlink for bin/ruby to bin/jruby
item.description: Add a bin/ruby symlink to bin/jruby, so minimalistic Ruby switchers (rbenv, rbfu, chruby) can switch to JRuby and use it as any other Ruby.
item.summary: Add symlink for bin/ruby to bin/jruby

comments.comment:
We've debated this on and off for a long time.

We provide "jruby" but not "ruby". But for everything else we use the standard names: "gem", "rake", "irb" (also "jirb"), etc.

I'm firmly on the fence here. I suppose you want this so you don't have to add your own symlink in chruby, right?

I'm not sure about precedent on this one...Rubinius doesn't do it, MacRuby doesn't do it, MagLev doesn't do it, etc. And for people with bin/ in PATH already, it would constitute a behavioral change; `ruby` would start running something different than it did before.

Rubinius does have a `ruby` symlink, both in source and that's installed into $PREFIX/bin. I think the real problem is that JRuby does not have an install task/script. If I'm installing JRuby into a non-standard location, then an optional `ruby` symlink could be added.

This is a big change request based on the number of people who are used to ruby launching native ruby and jruby launching jruby. We need to really consider the other unintended consequences for people who already depend on this behavior. In one sense, I would like to say it is a simple change because 1.7.0 is not actually out yet, but we are going to an RC release next. Seems like we will give little bake time to see what breaks.

FWIW, I think being totally consistent with all launchers naming is a good idea now. Having the special jruby but not special jrake is a consistent consistency question. It seems like we should make the change at some point. My main reservation is more about it happening for 1.7 versus 9k.

Ok, I'm game to give it a try. I will add a symlink from bin/ruby to bin/jruby and we'll see what happens.

At the very least I'll have to be more careful in my environment about what "ruby" command I run
